boardgame.name: Shaolin Chess
boardgame.description:
Shaolin Chess theme is a fantasy style, shaolin mortal combat. It combines some design aspects of Chinese Checkers with the moveset mechanics of Chess. The pieces representing some of the 5 most iconic Shaolin Styles: The Tiger, The Dragon, The Crane, The Snake and The Monkey.

Game play - Designed around an arena, up to 6 players compete in various (5) game modes for the title of Grand Master. Each player is given a set of "5 guard" pieces representing the styles. You must battle your way to victory in a blood bath of a game.

Goal of the game - To exercise a sense of strategy and understanding of others by building small inclusive communities.

Game modes - There are (5) different game modes. Each game mode can be made into a team match except for "Duel".

Duel - a game mode that resembles chess more than anything. You must capture your opponent's Grand Master piece. Accommodates between 2-3 players.

BloodBath - Last man standing wins.
Accommodates up to 6 players.

Dojo - Capture the flag like game, where your pieces must infiltrate an opponent's home base by reaching the furthest point in their dojo.
Accommodates up to 6 players.

Siege - An attacking Vs. Defender game, where an offensive team must capture all defending home bases, and the defending team must keep their bases safe.
Accommodates up to 6 players.

Enlightenment - A king of the hill type game, where players must race to the middle of the board, capture the grand master piece and keep control of the GM long enough to direct it back to their Dojos goal.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: The Game of Gates
boardgame.description:
Players take turns turning gates and moving pieces within the open paths created. The game is won by players moving their piece to the opposing players base, or by pinning the opposing players piece.

The game takes place on a 10x10 grid board with 45 gates. Player's bases are located in the far left corner of the back rows on each side of the board. Pieces are placed on their respective bases at the start of the game.

A turn consists of two actions in this order: a player turns any gate on the board, then a player moves their piece anywhere along the open path at least one space. Players take turns doing this until there is a winner.

boardgame.name: Blood Bowl (2016 edition): Spike! Journal #7
boardgame.description:
Take a Blood Bowl tour to the New World in Spike! Journal 7. Guest editor Pterry Dactyl plunges into the jungle to explore the exciting history of the game, rumoured to have been invented by the Slann and their Lizardmen servants.

The Lizardmen are ready to make a splash on the Blood Bowl scene. Combining the cold-blooded killer instinct and steely-eyed defence of Saurus Blockers with Skinks possessing speed and agility to rival the fastest teams on the pitch, the illustrious Lustrians play the game like they were spawned ready to play... because they were.

This issue is packed with everything you need to know about Lizardmen in Blood Bowl, and then some!


A Lustrian Adventure: setting out the broad history of Blood Bowl in the New World, and the various cold-blooded creatures that play it.
Background on famous Lizardmen teams, including the Gwaka’moli Crater Gators, plus stats, special rules and Star Player profiles!
Star Player Spotlight: Anqi Panqi - This massive Temple Guard Saurus is just what you need to shore up your line of scrimmage, and he only plays for Lizardmen. Take a look at his history, stats, and in-game cost.
Chat With the Rat: Hackspit ‘the Scribbler’ Quillchewer interviews Georgie Johns, an adventurer-archeologist who specializes in Lustrian history. He asks her a series of very oddly pointed questions about the history of Skaven-Lizardmen relations in the New World.
Star Player Spotlight: Glotl Stop - This Kroxigor doesn’t come cheap, but once you see what he can do for Lizardmen and Amazon teams, you’ll understand why. Dig into his background, rules and cost in this issue.
Lustrian Leagues: Run a season in Lustria and see how (some would say) the game is meant to be played! Take in the full rules for running matches in the temple-stadia, including rainforest weather patterns and an alternative kick-off table.
A Skink in the Plan: Top tips for getting the most out of the variety of players available to Lizardmen coaches. Here’s a hint: hide the quick, squishy little ones behind the big, scary ones until the last moment. You’re welcome!
Star Player Spotlight: Drull and Dribl - Get two for the price of one with twin Skinks! They’re surprisingly violent in all the right ways. Take a look at their unusual story, stats and the cost to add them to your roster.
Travellers from Beyond the Stars - A true and completely unbiased account of the Slann, the most powerful mages that ever lived, which we weren’t at all compelled to write by powerful sorceries. Plus, how to hire them as an Inducement for both Lizardmen and Amazon teams.
Dirt from the Dugout: Mindy Piewhistle dishes about the conflict between the priests of the Old Ones and those of Nuffle. There are… differences of opinion when it comes to the ‘right’ way to play.
Coffin Corner and Tatzina Babarini’s guide to Lustrian Style: You’re not going to find coverage like this anywhere else, folks. Get the inside scoop on these mysterious players and their home.
Classic Commentaries: Bob Bifford’s shares a riveting tale of a memorable game played against the Ssservants of the Ssslann. We double checked, and that’s definitely how it’s spelled.


Key Features

Rules and stats to field a Lizardmen team of your own
History of the Gwaka’moli Crater Gators and a slew of Star Players
Fascinating background on Lustria, and the origins of Blood Bowl itself


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Blood Bowl (2016 edition): Head Coach's Rules & Accessories Pack
boardgame.description:
Blood Bowl is the classic game of fantasy football. It’s all about strategy, grit, and – above all – heinous violence. Two players coach their teams to victory on the pitch, utilising every natural advantage, dirty trick, and cheap shot they can come up with to get the ball into the End Zone, or take out the entire opposing team.

This set contains all of the rules, gaming aids and accessories you need to get the most out of your games.

The 80-page Head Coach’s Handbook comes in a convenient A5-size to make it easy to handle whilst gaming. This essential tome is packed with the basic rules you need to play, plus extra rules for creating your own team and hiring staff. You'll also find a description of Special Play cards, and learn how to use them in your games. Official league rules help you set up and organise a season of gaming, complete with a dedicated stadium and sponsorship deals. There’s a handy chart of all the many Skills in the game, rosters for every single team that’s been released so far, plus every Star Player. Finally, there's even a section on the history of Blood Bowl to read while you're taking care of business that doesn't require your full attention!

But enough about the book. This box also contains loads of tokens to represent Inducements, player, game and weather status, re-rolls and tonnes more. You'll also find a super handy cheat sheet to look up the rules and tables you use most, a 50-page blank roster pad (go ahead and test that crazy team idea you've been kicking around), and a set of spare range, scatter and throw-in templates.

Key Features

Condensed rules, gaming aids and reference material
Rosters for every team, and Star Player rules
Tokens to keep track of all of the craziness Blood Bowl is known for


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: De Dwergen van Nidavellir
Nidavellir
Нидавелир
Нидавеллир
ニダヴェリア
니다벨리르
boardgame.description:
Nidavellir, the Dwarf Kingdom, is threatened by the dragon Fafnir. As a venerable Elvaland, you have been appointed by the King. Search through every tavern in the kingdom, hire the most skillful dwarves, recruit the most prestigious heroes, and build the best battalion you can to defeat your mortal enemy!

Each turn in Nidavellir, bid a coin on each tavern. In descending order, choose a character and add this character to your army. Each dwarf class has its own scoring way: blacksmith, hunter, warrior, explorer, and miner. A meticulous recruitment will allow you to attract a powerful hero to your army.

You will also be able to increase the value of your gold coins thanks to the smart "coin-building" system, and get the best of the other Elvalands.

The Dwarves of Nidavellir. Published by White Goblin Games. Designed by Serge Laget.
The Dwarves of Nidavellir is a bidding game. Dragon Fafnir has awakened and is looking for gold. The players are chosen by the king of the dwarfs to defeat the dragon. Increase the value of your gold coins, collect brave dwarves, recruit prestigious heroes. Form an army, defeat the dragon and win the game.
2 – 5 players From 10 years Game time: 45 minutes
You buy the game without risk, it is a swap game. You can always return the game and then you can exchange it for another game or get your 30 euros back. Unfortunately I cannot refund shipping costs. Please note that the rules are in Dutch only.
Shipping in Belgium to bpost collection point: +4.5 Shipping in Belgium with bpost to home address: +6 Shipping to the Netherlands to DPD collection point: +7.5 Collection or home delivery near 2060 Antwerp: +0 Other shippers certainly negotiable. I accept Paypal (a small extra Paypalfee can be charged), classic banktransfer or crypto.

boardgame.name: Victory in Hell: The First Battle of the Naktong River, August 5-19, 1950
boardgame.description:
“There will be no more retreating, withdrawal, readjustment of line or whatever you call it. There are no lines behind which we can retreat. This is not going to be a Dunkirk or Bataan. A retreat to Pusan would result in one of the greatest butcheries in history. We must fight to the end. We must fight as a team. If some of us die, we will die fighting together.” – US General Walton “Bulldog” Walker, July 31, 1950.

South Korean forces withdrew to a small perimeter centered on the South Korean port of Pusan. By August the North Korean forces, although bloodied by repeated US airstrikes and weakened by stragglers from their swift advance, were massed for what many thought would be a final offensive to take the rest of South Korea. The main focus of the North Korean attack was along the Naktong River where a small bridge head had been secured earlier. Victory here could insure that there would be only one Korea, ruled by Communist leader Kim Il Sung. A UN victory could buy time and set the stage for a counter-offensive that might send the Communists back and free South Korea. Can you do as well or better?

Each copy of "Victory in Hell" is composed of the following:


One 11 by 17 inch map.
One Players’ Aid Sheet with game tracks and terrain identification.
80 un-mounted double-sided units.
6 pages of rules.


Infantry units are regiments, all armor units are companies. A hex is approximately a third of a mile across. Each turn represents one day of time.

Players use a standard deck of playing cards to activate their units and determine some game events. A six-sided die is used to resolve game combats and other actions.

—description from the publisher

Also included with the download are images and maps that can easily be used to implement the module in Roll20 ot another virtual tabletop platform.

boardgame.name: The Ending of It All (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A 5th Edition Mini-Dungeon for 5-6 characters of level 20

Liikkua rested her hand on the great serpent’s head and spoke softly to her creation. The dragon was magnificent, even to a deity of travel who has seen unimaginable sights. Despite its awe-inspiring presence, it waited for her words. She talked of the codex and of how Hastur, the King in Yellow, fought to steal it, ransacking the infinite planes to find it. The guardian rumbled understanding, so Liikkua drew a simple map of six planes, separate from each other but connected by a sense of order. She folded it into a cube and shaped a key phrase for each face. She set the dragon and codex into the cube—despite it being just 2 inches on each side—and then picked up a simple atlas of 144 maps. She leafed through it and devised a mystery for each one, before allocating it to random future travelers. Then she pushed the cube through the tome’s cover, unaware of where it would end up, waiting to be found. But the concentration it took to complete the encasing ritual meant she missed the tiny yellow moth with tattered wings fluttering at her side. As she pressed the cube into the atlas, the moth landed on a face, leaving a diminutive, golden, star-shaped mark. It was in this way that Hastur inscribed his own key and entered the cube without the goddess knowing.

boardgame.name: The Werewolf (M&M)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A full moon rises high over the mist-filled moors. The sounds of glass shattering is heard, followed by a quickly-stifled scream. When others come to investigate, they discover they are too late. Blood and gore are everywhere. And in the distance a fearsome wolf's howl is heard. The werewolf is a monster that embodies the savage within all of humanity. An urge to break out from our facade of civilization, tear our clothes away, and live only for the hunt and the kill. These monsters care nothing for the lives of others, as humans are seen as simple prey to be consumed.

The monsters to be found in these "YOUniversal Monster" products are new builds, designed to be supervillains in their own right. They are PL 11 and have a variety of powers and abilities, ambitions, goals, and three different adventure ideas.

boardgame.name: Portraitgeist
boardgame.description:
One player will be taking on the role of a pesky poltergeist, Vincent VanGhost. Vincent has come to this mansion, to free his ghostly companions from their Portrait prisons in order to help him complete his ghastly rituals throughout the house. Vincent will be moving about the house in secret, using a separate pad to keep track of his movements, trying to free the other ghosts from their paintings. The painting ghosts will be moving about the house too but unlike Vincent, their movement is on the board for all to see. All the ghosts also have a unique movement advantage over the hunters, they can move through walls. As the ghosts are released freed, they will assist Vincent in completing rituals. To win the game they must complete 3 out of 5 rituals in 9 rounds of play. The other players will share control of the 4 hunters on the board. Each of these hunters has one of 10 different special powers to choose from giving each game a different way to combat Vincent and his ghostly pals. But if you think Vincent is without his own powers and tricks think again. Vincent too has different once per game powers to choose from, getting 3 to use each game. For the hunters to win they will need to locate Vincent and zap him, or hold him and his spooky pals at bay until the time limit expires.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: World War Zed: USA
boardgame.description:
This solitaire game pits you as the leader of the United States against an outbreak of Zombies or similar – called “Zeds” in the game. You must manage population centers, farmlands, refugees and the scientific and military response to the outbreak.

There are counters for Zeds, Riots, Refugees, Survivalists, the US Army, the US Marines, and the US National Guard. There are markers for Farms, Cities, Forts, and Nuclear Detonations.

The game map depicts the continental USA divided into 20 Regions from New York to Kansas to California. Game tracks on the map monitor food supplies, your remaining Production Points, and the DEFCON level among others.

8-Page Rulebook
Random Region and Events Sheet
20” x 17” Game Map
70 5-8 Inch Counters
38 3-4 Inch Counters
One Quickplay Sheet
A Scenario Book which includes Designer Notes

Besides the Basic Game, there are 15 special Zeds characteristics (Fast, Evolving, Aquatic, Flight, and More), 11 exciting scenarios, and 8 additional setups (including historical periods) for hours of thrilling fun as you command USA resources in the struggle against Zeds.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dead Men's Revenge
boardgame.description:
Quick Explanation of Dead Men's Revenge
After battling in BULLSHIP! to obtain the legendary Black Lagoon, players embark on their ships to race to Treasure Island, where they will amass riches and become the most powerful pirate king in the world.
The player who scored the last place from the original BULLSHIP! has come into contact with a deadly virus that has converted them into a contagious ZOMBIE! The Zombie could care less about Treasure Island - they solely want to convert all other players into Zombies and turn the sea into a zombie-infested undead haven.
The gameplay remains the same, however, with a twist. Each non-zombie player will move forward on the map only by winning BULLSHIP over another player. If a player loses to a Zombie player, they will instantly become a Zombie and their goal is to convert all other player's into Zombies. (Zombies VS Pirates VS Pirates)
The player who won first place from the original BULLSHIP! starts off closer to treasure island than the other players. (well deserved!)

boardgame.name: In the Heart of the Unknown
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

In the Heart of the Unknown – contains procedural Encounter, Terrain and Weather Engines for Wilderness Hex Crawling.

It is in a similar vein as ‘In the Heart of the Sea’, which is a procedural High Seas ‘Hex Crawl’.

Basically, in In the Heart of the Unknown there are three 'game engines' in the form of Hex Flowers. One engine drives navigation and encounters. The other two are related to terrain and weather conditions.

Each time you enter a new HEX, you procedurally determine what is in the new HEX starting from the last HEX result. So, Hex Flowers are sort of like a random table but with a memory.

Taverns are a common place for heroes to meet, learn about quests, and celebrate their heroic exploits. At The Moldy Unicorn, however, you will not find heroes. You will find scoundrels, monsters, knaves, and goons. You won’t find The Moldy Unicorn in a bright surface city or a friendly farming village. You’ll find it in one of the dark corners of the underworld, perhaps in a ramshackle goblin town, at the intersection of a forgotten underground highway, or on the outskirts of a necromancer’s undead fortress city. Drop The Moldy Unicorn into your campaign’s underworld and see what your players do with it.

This zine is meant to be played with Tunnel Goons but should be easy to use with other analog RPGs.

From publisher blurb:

Our oldest stories held our oldest fears.

Bestiary of Babylon presents the monsters of Babylon and the cities that came before for use in the Chronicles of Darkness. Inspired by Bygone Bestiary and Antagonists, the Bestiary presents four new monsters for the Chronicles of Darkness:

The Kullulu: Fish Demons who guard over wealth and prosperity and have taken a cruel interest in modern rituals of begging and crowdfunding.
The Rabisu: The lurkers in the door and the eaters of the dead, who consume all those who are dead... and those wicked enough that they might as well be.
The Girtablilu: Ancient guardians of the sacred and profane, who once tolerated the curiosities of humanity, but have learned long ago that humans cannot be trusted.
The Bull of Heaven: The Vengeance of the Gods themselves, the ancient city-destroying foe of Gilgamesh returns when called from the depths of space.


Each monster is presented in its original context and how they have adapted over the centuries as well as hooks to tie them to the other denizens of the Chronicles of Darkness. Each entry provides a full stat block as well as original art by Megan Taylor.

boardgame.name: A Magickal Fiasco: Full Tilt Story Creation for Mage
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

RANDOMLY GENERATE AN AMAZING TIME!

Maybe you're a new storyteller and you'd like some help getting your first chronicle going.
Maybe you're a profoundly experienced storyteller and you just want to add some oddities and complications to help bring a story to life.
Maybe you're a fan of Mage: The Podcast and you just want to subsidize my purchase of a new microphone.

This book. Will help. All of you. Probably.

A Magickal Fiasco: Full Tilt Story Creation for Mage is a guide to story seeding, a process where you randomly generate a web of relationships, intrigue, and motivations, hooks to get the story going, and some complications because no story ends how anyone thinks it should. Based on the wildly popular game Fiasco by Bully Pulpit Games, all you need are some 10-sided dice (or their digital equivalent), sticky notes (or their digital equivalent), and a dream (or its digital equivalent) and you too can create plot lines and story hooks never before seen in under an hour.

But I'm an amazing ST why would I use this?
Maybe you want to run a one shot, or characters encounter NPCs you've not planned, or a player said "oh yeah, I bet you couldn't run a randomly-generated plot from one of the guys at Mage: The Podcast" and you wish to prove that person wrong. In all these cases this tool will help.

What If There Was Another? A Breed Lost to the March of Time? Similar to the Garou, but Like the Nuwisha, Not of the Garou...
Tribebook Naghaluu is an exploration into an all new dire wolf fera for Werewolf: the Apocalypse. This all-new 59 page book is filled with the history, legends, and character options needed to play one of the Naghaluu.

The Naghaluu were active in the prehistoric Americas as Gaia's chosen Wyld hunters. They patrolled the darkest places of the land and paid a deep price to keep Gaia from being overwhelmed by the unchecked urges of the Wyld. boardgame.name: The Darkness Owns: The Lupines
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Vampire 1e's Werewolves, Updated for Vampire: the Masquerade Anniversary Edition!

“We spend a lot of time telling ourselves that we are at the very top of the food chain. Humanity lords over the world and we lord over them. Simple. Humans have no natural predators, save us… assuming we can call ourselves ‘natural.’ It is a very comfortable spot at the very top. It is soothing to think that we are our own worst enemies.

It is not true, of course. There is another level for which we serve as the prey."

+++

It is a well known truism within Kindred coteries; only the mad or desperate travel outside of the city. Outside is where the Lupines live. Outside is where the Kindred are weak and vulnerable. The Lupines hunt the Kindred, and are damn good at it. Better to just take a flight if you really must travel between cities.

...but sometimes the Kindred have to travel beyond the city's cacoon of concrete, glass, and steel. It is at those times they know real fear.

+++

Return to a time when Werewolves were Terrifying

The Darkness Owns: The Lupines features:

A new look at an old enemy from the Kindred's viewpoint - these aren't the Garou,
Written by an Ennie-winning veteran White Wolf and Vampire freelancer,

New legends and setting background for all versions of V:tM,
Example characters and packs to make it easy for Storytellers,
Writers' and editor's notes that discuss design decisions.

boardgame.name: ヘイッDJ (Hey DJ)
boardgame.description:
In this game, players are newbie DJs and begin practice sessions.
We will play a song card one by one in turn, but let's play songs that can be “mixed” with the previous songs as much as possible.
If it breaks somewhere, it will be scored by the person who played the song before that.

You can “mix” a song card that appears in play if you can put out a song with the same genre (color) or theme (icon) from your hand. Even if you cannot mix, be sure to play the card.
If the mix fails, the bunch of cards that have been in play until then will be scored.
The player who gets the score is the last player in the bundle.

Basically, each card is one point, but a card that matches the “My Genre Card” distributed in advance can be counted as two points.
Repeat until the deck is gone and the player with the most points wins.

—description from the designer (translated)

boardgame.name: Romans: Age of Caesar
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still in active development and available to the public for purchase in it's unfinished state, either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between).





Description Build Rome together! A co-operative grand strategy MMO from a team of veteran city builder developers, Romans: Age of Caesar is the latest historical strategy game from Stronghold developers Firefly Studios. Players must rebuild Rome as they share resources, re-establish trade routes and protect their cities from barbarian invasion. Experience classic city builder gameplay online across on an entire continent, working with fellow governors to rebuild the great cities of Rome. Revive the republic and restore the Roman Empire to its former glory!History Following the success of Stronghold Kingdoms, Firefly’s first ever MMO and cross-platform game, prototyping began on a spiritual successor that would become Romans: Age of Caesar. Building on the development of their first MMORTS, the team went about designing an online co-op city builder with thousands of players working together to rebuild Rome. The result is a shared world builder that returns to the classic Roman setting designer Simon Bradbury and producer Eric Ouellette made their name with before founding Firefly Studios. The game is currently in a limited closed Alpha test with a Beta and eventual release planned for later this year on PC and mobile.

Features


Build Rome Together – Co-operate with thousands of other players to rebuild the great cities and empire of Rome.
Grow Your Economy – Share resources, knowledge and legionnaires to expand your city with unique districts and features.
Perfect and Protect – Plan the roads, services and overall design of your economy while holding back barbarian hordes.
Reforge an Empire - Trade with fellow Romans, ally with your countrymen and crush the savages from England to Africa.
Kill Caesar – Barter or backstab your way to the top of the Senate. How long can YOU hold the title of Caesar?


Source: Official Wiki, "Romans: Age of Caesar Introduciton".

boardgame.name: SQU
boardgame.description:
INTRODUCTION

In SQU, players alternate turns placing stones on the board with the aim of creating the largest ‘squ’, an arrengement of 4 stones in the corners of a square.

SQU adds up to the family of other ‘square-creation games’ such as Dakapo (Stephan Miksch) or Quartetto (Artyom Tchebotaryov). It also uses the 1-2-2-2… piece-entering mechanism of Connect6 to balance the game.

EQUIPMENT

10x10 orthogonal board (checkered for clarity) with an inner 8x8 board for shorter games, 50 red discs, 50 black discs, 4 red pyramids, 4 black pyramids, carrying case.

HOW TO PLAY

Definition: a Squ is an arrangement of 4 discs of the same colour on the corners of a square with the sides parallel to the sides ot the board (this is, the square must not be rotated).

Each player has an allocated colour (Red or Black).

The board starts empty. Decide the size of the board (8x8 or 10x10).

Red places one disc onto an empty cell of the board. Then, starting with Black, players alternate turns placing 2 discs of their colour onto empty spaces until either one of the players resigns or all cells are occupied.

If, at the end of a player’s turn (after placing both stones) a squ bigger than any previous squ of any colour has been created, the player places one pyramid of her colour on each of the 4 corners of that squ (covering each of the 4 discs). This is, the pyramids are used to keep track of the largest squ of each colour. Notice that the discs covered by pyramids still count for future squs.

HOW TO WIN

When the game ends, the player with the largest squ wins the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: White Eagle Defiant: Poland 1939
boardgame.description:
White Eagle Defiant, the follow-up game to the bestselling Brave Little Belgium, recreates the German, Slovak and Soviet invasion of Poland in September and October 1939 that marked the beginning of the Second World War. Germany and its Slovakian ally began the invasion on September 1, 1939; the Soviet Union followed suit on the 17th. Known in Poland as the September Campaign and in Germany by the codename Fall Weiss (Case White), the campaign ended on October 6, 1939 with Germany and the Soviet Union splitting the country in two.

In White Eagle Defiant, one player controls the Germans, Slovaks and Soviets (simplified as the Germans in the game) while the other player commands the Poles. The German objective is to gain control of Warsaw and other designated Victory cities while preventing Polish forces from destroying their forts in East Prussia and recapturing Victory cities. If the German player does so in less time than the historical campaign, they win the game. Anything less is a draw or a win for the Polish player.

This quick-playing wargame employs very similar mechanics as Brave Little Belgium, but with a modest increase in complexity. The game uses a point-to-point map and a chit pull mechanism to simulate the campaign, with each turn representing four days. Random event chits are included to add variety and excitement to the game, reflecting the weapons (such as armored trains and aerial bombardment) used at the beginning of World War II. The combat system, while still simple, is enhanced to better simulate mechanized warfare, as well as the use of combined forces (players can bring forces from adjacent spaces into an attack, creating primary and secondary combat groups).

Other new features in White Eagle Defiant include Panzers for the Germans (which can roll two dice instead of one) and cavalry for the Poles (which can roll a “first shot” at the beginning of a combat round). A Victory Point track allows for variable entry of Soviet forces (depending on the success of the German player in capturing Victory cities), as well as the possibility of the Allies launching an attack in the West (if the German player fails to do well in capturing Victory cities). Finally, a “blitzkrieg breakdown” track is used by the German player; if the turn ends before both German army group chits are pulled, the German player may elect to activate a group, but possibly suffer a “breakdown” while doing so – and if five such breakdowns occur, the German player automatically loses the game.

Players who enjoyed Brave Little Belgium will find that White Eagle Defiant offers the same tense play for both sides, while presenting new challenges that reflect the dawn of the blitzkrieg era.

—description from the designer
boardgame.boardgamehonor: 2020 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Boardgame Nominee

boardgame.name: Girls Night Out: The Pre-Game
boardgame.description:
Be the perfect HOST with this hilarious and risqué start to any girls gathering or bachelorette party. Your girls will love you for it. Grab some drinks and get your pre-game on!

Plays up to 6 people
Includes 81 FUNNY question cards
24 response cards
Adults only! (NOT for kids)
Comes in a white box

Girls Night Out is a conversational game. There are two ways to play:

Rotate reading the cards or select one person to read cards for the group. Each player gets voting cards (A, B, C, and D). Everyone votes with their card face down, then reveal. The answer with the majority wins. Players that voted for the majority get a point. Play to a predetermined number or number of rounds.
Use the cards as conversation starters. Read each card and discuss the options. No Voting.


Variations:

Drinking Game(21+): Instead of each player receiving a point for voting for the majority, players that didn't vote for the majority must take a drink. (Please play responsibly)
Reveal: Each player who chose a non-majority answer must reveal an intimate secret about themselves or accept a dare from the other players.
Three Strikes: Choose three non-majority answers and you're out of the game. Last one still in wins.
Gambling: Each player wagers before the hose reads the answer choices for a question. If you can answer the card correctly after the options are read out loud, you win. If you win, you gain all of the points wagered. In the case of a tie, no one wins. If you lose, whoever wins will receive your points.


Example Card:
What's the worst thing that can happen at your wedding?
A. Your ex pops up
B. The groom shows up late
C. The families start fighting
D. Someone spills something on your dress

boardgame.name: 8-Cylinder Overlords
boardgame.description:
8-Cylinder Overlords is a game of building, defending, and attacking roads in a post-collapse world. 2-4 players take on the roles of Overlords, human brains encased in heavily-armed and armored supercars that rule over auto-worshipping Pedestrians. There are only a few Overlords left and they are racing to build a Road to a Lost City of forgotten lore and restorative technology. The first player to complete a 20-30 space long Road and drive her Overlord to the end wins the game!

Each Player draws cards from the Road deck and lays down the cards in a line to form their Road. Simple Pavement cards extend the Road. Installation cards give you many more options: Farms allow you to create more workers. Refineries create the Fuel that you must pay to build each part of your Road and to compete in the Auction phase. Fortresses allow you to attack your rivals' Roads with withering Barrages or daring and potentially lucrative Raids. Once the Card is added to the Road, Players crew their installations by placing Peds in the spaces on each card. Players then go through the breeding, refining, and attacking phases and end their turn with the option of selling any cards they don't use.

During every phase of a Player's turn, the Overlord figure has a special ability that can be used to augment the action, such as drawing more cards, motivating installations to act again, directly attacking rival Roads, and more. But each Overlord Action costs fuel from the Overlord's reserve and Players must make good choices about when to use these additional abilities.
After each round of turns, Players move to Walkerville, a neutral territory where upgrades, special power cards, more workers, and various unique actions are sold in blind auctions. If two or more players compete for a single auction item and reach the maximum bid, the issue is decided by a frantic, high-stakes Drag Race. Auction wins can dramatically turn the tide of the game and Players are encouraged to bid aggressively.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Scratch The Deck
boardgame.description:
Scratch The Deck: A cool card game for people who love Cats!

Be the first to get rid of all your cards, plan your end game strategically to win and be the Scratch the Deck Champion.

Each player is dealt 4 cards face up and 9 cards face down. The 4 cards face up are to be kept in hand and the 9 cards face down cannot be seen or used until the end of the game when there is no more deck cards to draw from (9 Lives End Game).

Each turn players must lay a card of equal or higher value than the player before, for example: on top of a 4, you can lay a 4 or higher. If you have multiples of the same number you can lay them at the same time. If you lay 4 or more of the same number, you can Scratch the Deck (discard the pile and lay a new start card). As long as there are cards left in the deck, players must keep a minimum of 4 cards in hand at all times, so, if you lay 2 cards, you pick up 2, if you lay 1 card, you pick up 1.

Every time you place a card of the same value of the player before, for example: you lay a 5 on top of a 5, you pick a card up from the 'Good Cat Bad Cat' deck. Good Cat Cards offer advantages to players that can be helpful to the player (especially during the 9 lives end game) and Bad Cat Cards make the game harder for the player.

Super Power Cat Cards (Can be placed on any card, almost):
1 = Can be laid on any card and is the lowest value card in the game
3 = Can be placed under the pile (Hide Card)
6 = Can be laid on any card, the next player must play a double (2 or more cards of the same value) or Alpha (11 or 12) card next
9 = Can be laid on any card, the next player must lay lower than a 9
10 = Can be laid on any card, the card pile is discarded and a new start card is laid (Scratch the Deck)

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Headman's Revenge
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Spooky One-Shot Adventure
Recommended for 4-6 player characters of levels 6 to 8

A quaint forest village is being visited by a terror from its past.
Each night this Headless Horseman kidnaps one unlucky soul.
Can you stop the fiend before he destroys this village?

Hello and welcome, adventurers and Game Masters!

This is a spooky, holiday themed one-shot module designed for an evening’s worth of adventuring on Samhain, or as it is better known in the modern world, Halloween!

SYNOPSIS: The adventure takes place in the quaint village of Coomchadalach, which lies on the borderlands between the nations of nations of Alderburgh and The Red Eagle Barony. This was a peaceful place where folk tended to respect themselves, each other and the law. Above all else they sought to keep the Balance, for their faith was that passed down from the druids of old, who still minister to the villagers here to this day.

Everything here was in Balance…until recently that is, when a group of foolhardy, young travelling “heroes” raided the abandoned graveyard at the end of the hollow, disturbing the rest of the undead headman imprisoned there, and released his spirit to prey upon the populace of Coomchadalach. Now, the evil spirit has returned nightly to exact its revenge on both the young heroes and the descendants of the original villagers who sentenced him to death so long ago! Each night it takes a prisoner, burns their abode, and drags them back to its hovel in the abandoned graveyard, there to be slain and brought back as a new recruit in its army of the undead!

The Balance cannot be maintained now, as the foul, murderous thing these young adventurers have released is none other than a supernatural undead being called a dullahan, better known in some parts as a Headless Horseman! Worst still the dullahan is working in league with its demonic patron, a greater power of the hells, who has plans to crush the forces of Light and take over the known world, shattering the Balance and plunging the entire world into Darkness!

You and your friends have just ridden into the village of Coomchadalach. You are not quite sure how you ended up here as you had no intention of doing so, but time and again circumstance on the road (a felled tree, a flooded ford, and etc.) forced you in this direction, and so here you are. You quickly realize your help is needed as these folk are facing an extraordinary, otherworldly foe they cannot hope to defeat. However, as seasoned adventurers, this is what you do! A travelling priestess named Mother Mabon and the village council are offering a sizeable reward if you will defeat the dullahan, rescue the kidnapped villagers, and help restore the Balance.

Will you help them, heroes?

This adventure is intended for a party of 4-6 players of 6th to 8th level, and a fully prepared group of pre-generated player characters is included for use by players or the GM as NPCs. Another set of four pre-generated player characters (the young adventurers) are also detailed and may be used as NPCs as well. This supplement contains a completely original ONE SHOT adventure, fully detailed and ready for immediate use with very little preparation by the GM or the players! The module includes new, never before seen were-beasts and new magic items for use in your campaign!

boardgame.name: Blood Moon
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Lycanthropic One-Shot Adventure
Recommended for 4-6 player characters of levels 4 to 6

The Hambills are a well-respected farming family in Baile Atha Quinith society.
But no one has heard from them, and those sent to investigate never returned!
Can you discover what tragedy befell these poor souls on the last blood moon?

Hello and welcome, adventurers and Game Masters!

In this one-shot adventure, your players are new arrivals to the grand capitol city of The Red Eagle Barony, Baile Atha Quinith. Upon their arrival they are contacted by the crown’s Spymistress, who requests their assistance in a matter of some urgency and delicacy. Her master, the High Clerk of the court, is seeking adventures to investigate the goings on at a local farm: the farmers have not been heard from since the recent blood moon and the military unit sent to investigate never returned! While delving into this mystery, your players will uncover a lycanthropic invasion, and they must confront and defeat these shape shifters to secure the farmstead and rescue any survivors of the Hambill family!

This adventure is intended for a party of 4-6 players of 4th to 6th level, and a fully prepared group of six pre-generated player characters is included for use by players or the GM as NPCs. This supplement contains a completely original ONE SHOT adventure, fully detailed and ready for immediate use with very little preparation by the GM or the players! The module includes new, never before seen were-beasts and new magic items for use in your campaign!

Inside this module you will find great Old-school art and detailed maps of the capitol city of Baile Atha Quinith, the Royal and North Wards of the capitol, and the Hambill farm (with a GM’s map of keyed encounters and a player’s map). This module also includes a detailed world map of the nation of The Red Eagle Barony, done in the Old School style, with areas for further exploration.

The module can be completed in a single 3-4 hour sessions, or if combined with other our other published modules it provides a story-arc which will span numerous gaming sessions! This story arc begins in SO8 Sea Hag’s Folly, continues in SO13 Shrine of Sacrifice, moves on to this module, and concludes in the forthcoming module Against the Unholy!

This adventure also provides further details on the nation of The Red Eagle Barony, revealing the history of the barony for the very first time! The Red Eagle Barony, along with the nations of Alderburgh, Jarlburgh, Dùn Bhriste and The Dales, brings the author’s camping world to five separate nation states to explore!

boardgame.name: Little Nightmares - Secrets of the Maw
Little Nightmares - The Depths
Little Nightmares: Complete Edition
boardgame.description:
A young boy, known as the Runaway Kid (Nintendo switch version, “The Kid”), wakes up from a nightmare involving him swimming in darkness before being dragged underwater. After leaving the Nursery, he spots the Janitor chasing one of the escaping children. The Kid follows a girl who is also fleeing, but she disappears and leaves her flashlight behind, which the Kid takes.

The Kid finds himself in the Depths of the Maw, which are heavily flooded and he has to avoid Leeches and make his way across by hopping on floating platforms. The Depths turn out to be the home of the Granny, who swims underwater and attempts to grab the Kid either by bumping and destroying the platforms he stands on or snatching him if he is in the water for too long. After pushing a television set into the water to electrocute and kill the Granny, the Kid makes his way to a tall wooden staircase with light coming through the top. He then reaches a ladder and climbs it, pushing through a grate. However, the light turns out to be a flashlight and he is caught by the Janitor and dragged into the darkness. The final scene shows the Kid in a cage next to other cages with children, including Six. The Janitor's long arms reach out and grab the Kid's cage and pull it off screen, paralleling Six's campaign just before she wakes up in the cage.

Source: Wikipedia, "Little Nightmares", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Little Nightmares - Secrets of the Maw
Little Nightmares - The Hideaway
Little Nightmares: Complete Edition
boardgame.description:
The second DLC chapter is titled "The Hideaway" and features the Kid and the Nomes.[6] It starts with the Kid escaping from the paper he is wrapped in, which is ascending on a hook towards the Kitchen, and he falls to a new level of the Maw. With the help of the Nomes that he finds along the way, he finds an engine room where the Nomes are brought to throw coal in the furnace. One of the rooms in the area has a similar viewing machine as in the Lair, where the Kid can see places where Six has been, and he even witnesses Six herself treading through the sea of shoes. During this campaign, the Kid also encounters the Janitor. After finding all the Nomes and bringing them to the engine room to help power up the furnace, the large bucket elevator in the back of the engine room becomes fully functional, ultimately lifting the Kid up to where the Nomes are gathered, presumably the "Hideaway". The shadows indicate that the Nomes actually are or have been children. Then, after leaving through a crack in the wall, the Kid eventually finds himself on a rising platform, which is the top of an elevator where the Lady is standing.

Source: Wikipedia, "Little Nightmares", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.description:
The chapter starts at the top of the elevator where the Lady was at the end of the Hideaway. In this campaign, the Kid finds himself in the Lady's Residence, eventually finding a room with several statues of the Lady. After solving puzzles to find three missing statues, while fighting off the Shadow Children, he finds the Lady looking at herself in a mirror. The Lady is revealed to have a gruesome face, possibly explaining why she wears a mask. In the last room of the Residence, the Lady captures the Kid and transforms him into a Nome. He then finds his way to the Guest Area and then to the room with the sausage in Six's campaign. The chapter ends with the Kid standing by the sausage, indicating that it is him who Six eats. When the credits for the Secrets of the Maw roll, they are eventually shown on a television set, after which the screen shows a figure reminiscent of the Hanging Man.

Source: Wikipedia, "Little Nightmares", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Who am I?
boardgame.description:
Who am I? is a deduction game where player's goal is to deduce the animal and two pieces of clothing an opponent is holding. On a player turn, they can give an animal card to opponent who then has to answer if any of the pictured items match their hidden cards. After collecting enough evidence that a player can prove any of the hidden cards, they can do so. Finding out all three hidden cards wins the game.

boardgame.name: Exagon
boardgame.description:
Exagon is an abstract tile laying game. Players distribute hexagonal tiles equally between them and start placing them in such way that edges match to neighboring pieces. If only one edge matches, the turn is over. If two or more edges match, that player has a 60 second sand timer to place as many tiles as they can match in a similar way. First to get rid of their tiles is the winner.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Ghoullotine
boardgame.description:
Ghoullotine is a fast and ghoulish card game with some themes inspired by the likes of Blackjack.

Each player has a hand of 3 cards that they must use to the best of their ability. During a player’s turn, they will play 1 card from their hand, it’s number is added to the total. Then, if the total is above “13”, then that player is removed from the game. If the total isn’t higher than “13”, then the effect of the card activates. Such effects may be the “Witch’s” ability to swap hands with another player or the “Ghoul’s” ability to skip a player’s next turn.

This game has a surprising amount of tricks and tactics to employ, that’ll keep you addicted to this treat of a game.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Heldenwerk-Archiv 3
Heldenwerk-Archiv III
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb

The Hero Work Archive III unites seven short adventures that lead your heroes to different regions, and even times, of Aventuria. Six of these adventures come from the Hero's Work series, the seventh was made especially for this anthology. All adventures have been provided with an author's commentary and additional material for the Hero's Work Archive.
The Changeable Destiny takes you to the deadly jungle of Maraskan Island, where you'll explore the ruins of the Tuzak Mage Academy.
The dark Mhanadi shows the other side of the Gulf of Tuzak, the Mhanadi Delta at Khunchom, where many dangers lurk for the heroes.
Crossed blades let you experience how the Hora Empire developed after the events in Disaster over Arivor and what political decisions are pending there.
Grim hearts take us to the margraviate of Warunk. It's freed from demonic domination, but still far from inviting or safe for travelling heroes.
The return to the forest without return is at the same time a return to the origins of DSA. A leap through time and systems takes us on a whole new DSA1 adventure in the
Retro look of the 80s.
Tyrannicide brings us back to the current timeline and leads us back to more southern climes. Here the heroes interfere with the fate of a ruler in the caliphate.
Finally, the heroes search for hope in the darkness in the Shadowlands, a place that is not necessarily famous for hopeful days, but is infamous for its extremely dark hustle and bustle.


Klappentext

Das Heldenwerk-Archiv III vereint sieben Kurzabenteuer, die deine Helden in verschiedene Regionen, und sogar Zeiten, Aventuriens führen. Sechs dieser Abenteuer entstammen der Heldenwerk-Reihe, das siebte wurde speziell für diesen Sammelband angefertigt. Alle Abenteuer wurden für das Heldenwerk-Archiv mit einem Autorenkommentar und Zusatzmaterial ausgestattet.
Des Wandelbaren Schicksal führt euch in den tödlichen Dschungel der Insel Maraskan, wo es die Ruinen der Magierakademie von Tuzak zu erkunden gilt.
Der dunkle Mhanadi zeigt die andere Seite des Golfs von Tuzak, das Mhanadi-Delta bei Khunchom, wo viele Gefahren auf die Helden lauern.
Gekreuzte Klingen lässt euch erleben, wie sich das Horasreich nach den Ereignissen in Unheil über Arivor entwickelt hat und welche politischen Entscheidungen dort anstehen.
Grimme Herzen entführt uns in die Markgrafschaft Warunk. Diese ist zwar befreit von dämonischer Herrschaft, aber noch lange nicht einladend oder sicher für reisende Helden.
Die Rückkehr in den Wald ohne Wiederkehr ist gleichzeitig eine Rückkehr zu den Ursprüngen von DSA. Ein Sprung durch die Zeit und die Systeme entführt uns zu einem ganz neuen DSA1-Abenteuer im
Retro-Look der 80er.
Tyrannenmord lässt uns in die aktuelle Zeitlinie zurückkehren und führt uns in südlichere Gefilde zurück. Hier mischen sich die Helden in die Geschicke eines Herrschers im Kalifat ein.
Hoffnung in der Finsternis suchen die Helden schließlich in den Schattenlanden, einem Ort der nicht unbedingt berühmt für hoffnungsvolle Tage, aber dafür für äußerst finsteres Treiben berüchtigt ist.

boardgame.name: Shifting Realms: Darkness Revealed
boardgame.description:
Shifting Realms: Darkness Revealed is an expansion to Shifting Realms. A copy of Shifting Realms is necessary to play Darkness Revealed. The base game includes 5 realms which are played 3 at a time offering 10 realm combinations and 60 unique board layouts. Shifting Realms:Darkness Revealed comes with 2 additional realms bringing the number of realm combinations to 35 with 210 board layouts.

The two new realms in Darkness Revealed are Knossos and Gehenna. Each realm comes with a board, structures, story cards, and task cards. The new realms introduce new synergies, mechanisms, and components to the base game.

Knossos, the undiscovered land of the minotaurs, introduces Search tiles and Labyrinth walls. Players need to search areas of the board to recover treasure before structures can be built in the realm. Players can place Labyrinth walls to block movement and building adjacency. Players also start the game drafting story cards which ramps up the first few turns of the game.

Gehenna, the dark land of the demons, offers players ways to directly interfere with the other players. Building Demon Towers enables players to capture opposing players units for victory points. Many of the story cards in this realm enable players to move opponents’ units within the realms.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Sphärenklang - Das Dornenreich
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb

The fairy-tale cities of the Thorn Kingdom are home to phex-favorable merchants, astute stargazers, and mysterious Qabalya sects struggling for power and influence at the court of the Rose Princess. Immerse yourself in the sounds of Arania and let yourself be enchanted!
This audio CD was conceived by Ralf Kurtsiefer and the Ulisses editorial team, this time under the direction of Zoe Adamietz, in order to provide musical accompaniment to the numerous facets of Arania.
In the Dornenreich cultural influences of the Middle Kingdom and the Tulamidenlande meet at eye level. But instead of competing, they arrive at a synthesis that brings with it a truly unique attitude to life.
Running time approx. 50 minutes


Klappentext

Die märchenhaften Städte des Dornenreiches sind die Heimat phexgefälliger Händler, scharfsinniger Sterndeuterinnen und geheimnisvoller Qabalya-Sekten, die um Macht und Einfluss am Hofe der Rosenherrscherin ringen. Tauche ein in die Klangwelt Araniens und lass dich verzaubern!
Diese Audio-CD wurde von Ralf Kurtsiefer und der Ulisses-Redaktion, diesmal federführend von Zoe Adamietz, konzipiert, um die zahlreichen Facetten Araniens musikalisch zu untermalen.
Im Dornenreich begegnen sich kulturelle Einflüsse des Mittelreichs und der Tulamidenlande auf Augenhöhe. Doch anstatt zu konkurrieren, gelangen sie zu einer Synthese, die ein wahrlich einzigartiges Lebensgefühl mit sich bringt.
Laufzeit ca. 50 Minuten
